Defines

#define COMPEL_API   __stdcall
 Defines the calling convention used.
#define COMPEL_EXPORT   extern "C" __declspec(dllimport)
 Designates whether this library is used as a DLL or static library.

COMPEL_EXPORT int COMPEL_API compel_script_interpret_line (compel_script_t, const char *)
 Executes the user's line.
You may use this command to continously interpret commands without clearing previous commands. This command will add lines to previously loaded script. So if you reset the execution line to ZERO then you will run everything all over again.

 Registers user's command without using the usercommand_info_t structure. User defined commands are commands provided by the 3rd party developer and are exposed to the scripting engine.

*COMPEL_API 		compel_script_avail_extensions ()
 Returns the available extensions.
The extensions are semicolon separated. Extensions are built-in language commands. You may chose to disable all built-in extensions by passing no extension to the compel_script_init().
COMPEL_EXPORT long COMPEL_API compel_parse_number (const char *value)
 Parses a numeric value from the string.
Given a string, it returns a number It can parse hex numbers of the form: 0xNNNN and NNNNh, also parses octal numbers of the form: 0NNN.

 Creates a string with the given size.
This function simply uses COMPEL's memory manager to allocate a string.

 Destroys a previously allocated string.
This is useful when COMPEL returns strings that you may need to free later using this function.

COMPEL_API 		compel_tokenize_init (const char *str, const char *delim, const char *quote, const char *escape)
 Creates a string tokenizer object.
This function also tokenizes, so you can directly extract the values.

*COMPEL_API 		compel_tokenize_set (compel_tokenizer_t, const size_t idx, const char *str)

Detailed Description

COMPEL library header.

This library exports methods to be used by COMPEL users. All calls are exported and can be called from almost any language that supports stdcall calling convention

Last updated on 05/11/2006, 10:43 AM

Typedef Documentation

typedef struct _compel_init_t compel_init_t
 

COMPEL library initialization structure. This is used when you call script engine initialization function.

See also:
compel_script_init()

compel_lib_usercommand_cb_t
 

This is the prototype for the user defined commands.

See also:
compel_lu_cmd_register2()

compel_object_t
 

ADT defining object_t types.

See also:
compel_value_create compel_value_find

compel_script_error_handler_cb_t
 

Error handler callback prototype.

See also:
compel_script_set_error_handler()

typedef void* compel_script_t
 

ADT defining the scripting engine type This type is passed to most function calls, to select which script should the call be applied on.

See also:
compel_script_init

compel_tokenizer_t
 

ADT defining the string tokenizer object.

See also:
compel_tokenize_init()

typedef struct _compel_init_t * p_compel_init_t
 

COMPEL library initialization structure. This is used when you call script engine initialization function.

See also:
compel_script_init()

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum compel_errors_e
 

COMPEL library error codes returned.

These error codes are returned by some of the library calls

Enumerator:
compel_error_success  Success.
compel_error_symbol_undefined  An undefined symbol occured.
compel_error_syntax_error  Script syntax error.
compel_error_error_handler_continue_search  The error handler decided to pass the error to next handlers.

See also:
compel_script_set_error_handler()
compel_error_wrong_param_count  Wrong parameters passed to a given command, eiter more or less commands passed.
compel_error_function_expected  A command call was expected.
compel_error_script_stopped  The script has been stoped either because it encountered END or fatal script error.
compel_error_symbol_redefined  Symbol was redefined.
compel_error_unknown_error  An unknown error occured. This should usually never occur.
compel_error_branch_handled  We adjusted script line number, the engine should not advance the script line number. The user command changed the source line number, thus the engine should not advance to next line. This is useful if you write some sort of branching commands.
compel_error_symbol_expected  A symbol rather than a constant was expected. The symbol may.
compel_error_wrong_param_value  A wrong parameter value was generated or passed. For example, a divide by zero operation might return this value.
compel_error_no_operation  The instruction yields nothing because it can be:
  • empty line
  • void line
  • comment line.

enum compel_internal_e
 

COMPEL internal command codes. These codes are used with compel_internal(). The arg1 parameter can hold any of the listed values. The rest of the arguments depend on the arg1 value.

Enumerator:
compel_internal_writeraw  This allows you to write the prepared (processed) script lines into a file arg2 can optionally point to a pointer to the raw file name. It returns 0 if failure to write or 1 if write successful
compel_internal_setdbgout  This will enable or disable the outputing of the interpreted lines. arg2 can be 0 or 1 to enable or disable
See also:
_compel_init_t b_dbgout_script
compel_internal_showlines  This flag will allow COMPEL engine to dump all the script lines to stdout
compel_internal_showsymtbl  This flag will allow COMPEL to dump the contents of the symbol table to stdout
compel_internal_pause  Interrupts the execution of the script
compel_internal_exectime  Get the execution time in milliseconds

Converts from engine to lib error (this method is used internally).

COMPEL_EXPORT long COMPEL_API compel_parse_number (  const char *  value  ) 
 

Parses a numeric value from the string.
Given a string, it returns a number It can parse hex numbers of the form: 0xNNNN and NNNNh, also parses octal numbers of the form: 0NNN.

Parameters:
value_str the string value
Returns:
The numeric value or 0 if not a valid numerical string was passed

COMPEL_EXPORT const char* COMPEL_API compel_script_avail_extensions (   ) 
 

Returns the available extensions.
The extensions are semicolon separated. Extensions are built-in language commands. You may chose to disable all built-in extensions by passing no extension to the compel_script_init().

See also:
_compel_init_t

COMPEL_EXPORT void COMPEL_API compel_script_context_set (  compel_script_t  ,
void *  context
) 
 

Associates a user tag with the given script object.
This is useful if you want to refer to some special value from inside a user commands.

Parameters:
context Any tag value that user wants to associate with the script object

COMPEL_EXPORT char* COMPEL_API compel_script_evaluate_expression (  compel_script_t  compel_script,
const char *  expr,
bool  bKeepQuotes,
char  chDelim
) 
 

Evaluates an expression. The expression is a variable name or names of any sort. The expression value is the same value as one would use var extension to create an initialed variable.

Parameters:
expr The expression to evaluate
Returns:
A compel_string_create() string containing the expression value. Make sure you free the returned buffer through compel_string_destroy
See also:
compel_string_destroy

)

compel_value_t variable's reference
value The new value

)
